The extra stoichiometry from the near end…

- The question: Assuming that 1 billion (1,000,000,000) metric tons of 3% sulfur coal was burned in America every year, and all of it was converted to SO2 (sulfur dioxide), how many tons of limestone would be needed to scrub out 100% of that sulfur?

- Using both of the same equations from earlier in the video:

n(sulfur) = [(30kg/ton) × 1,000,000,000] × (1,000g/kg) × (mol/32.065g)

n(sulfur) = 30,000,000,000 × (1,000g/kg) × (mol/32.065g)

n(sulfur) = 30,000,000,000,000 × (mol/32.065g)

n(sulfur) = 935,599,563,387 mol (for 1 billion metric tons of 3% sulfur coal burnt)

- Since all of the sulfur from the burned coal is converted to SO2, 64.0638g is used for the molarity in the next equation since that is the atomic mass of SO2.

m(SO2) = 935,599,563,387 mol × (64.0638g/1 mol) × (1kg/1,000g) × (1 ton/1,000kg)

- After multiplying (935,599,563,387) mol and (64.0638g/1 mol), I simplified the last two units, (1kg/1,000g) and (1 ton/1,000kg) to (1 ton/1,000,000g) in the next part to make the equation a bit cleaner.

m(SO2) = 5,993,781,156,912g × (1 ton/1,000,000g)

OR

m(SO2) = 5,993,781,156,912g/1,000,000g

m(SO2) = 5,993,781.16 tons (to the nearest hundredth)

So, in order to scrub out 100% of the SO2 (sulfur dioxide) created when 1 billion metric tons of 3% sulfur coal was burned in the United States, you would need 5,993,781.16 (or approximately 6 million) metric tons of limestone.

With the conversion rate in the video, of the sulfur in 1 ton of coal reacting with 93.6 kg of limestone, 1 billion tons will react with 93.6 billion kilograms of limestone, otherwise written as 93.6 million tons, or 93,600,000 million kilograms, or 93,600,000,000,000 kilograms, or an estimated 15,600 Great Pyramids of Giza. But this is not all. Each mole of sulfurous acid will also cause 1 mole each of carbon dioxide and water vapor to be released. This equates to 935 billion moles of each, and thus 41,140,000 tons of CO2 and 16,830,000 tons of gaseous H2O. So... yeah... some pretty heavy stuff if you ask me.

94 million (9.4x10^7) metric tons of limestone per 1 billion tons of 3% sulfur coal.


1,000,000,000 tons of coal * (30kgS/1tonCoal) * (1000gS/1kgS) * (1molS/32.066gS) = 9.356x10^11molS.


Same amount of mols Sulfur per Limestone, therefore, 9.356x10^11molS = 9.356x10^11molCaCO3 (Limestone).


9.356x10^11molCaCO3 * (100.078gCaCO3/1molCaCO3) = 9.36*10^13gCaCO3.


9.36*10^13gCaCO3 * (1 metric ton/10^6gCaCO3) = 9.36*10^7 metric tons of limestone, around 94 million metric tons.

As we learn, burning coal emits sulfates.  Fun fact:  These sulfates reflect sunlight back into space, so burning coal both emits greenhouse gas, CO2, and a greenhouse negating gas, sulfates.  The devil in the details, however, is that the CO2 persists for hundreds of years in the atmosphere while the sulfates fall out in only a matter of weeks.  So if we were to stop burning coal tomorrow, very quickly there would be a fast spike in global warming to the tune of about 1 degree C.

I got 320679320.679. Here's my process:

1) Find 3% of 1 billion, which is 30,000,000.
2) Find the amount of grams in 30,000,000 kilograms, which is 30,000,000,000.
3) Find the amount of sulfuric moles in 30,000,000,000 grams , which is 963,000,000,000.
4) Find how much Calcium Carbonate this translates to, as Calcium carbonate has a molar mass of 100.1, ANS = 9620379620.38 grams.
5) Reduce this number back to kilograms, which ends up being a tidy 9620379.62038 kilograms, or about 9620 metric tons.

The answer to the question in the video:
Since a ton (1000kg) of coal produces 30kg of sulfur, a billion tons (1,000,000,000kg) would produce 30,000,000kg (30,000,000,000g) of sulfur.
The molar mass for limestone (CaCO3) is 32.1 g/mol.
30,000,000,000 g ÷ 32.1 g/mol = 934,579,439.3 moles of sulfur.
Since one mole of sulfur equals one mole of CaCO3 used, 934,579,439.3 moles of limestone is needed.
The molar mass of CaCO3 is 100.1 g/mol.
934,579,439.3 mol × 100.1 g/mol = 9.36 × 10^10 g = 93,4441,401.87 kg of CaCO3
93.4 million kilograms (94 thousand tons) of limestone would be used.

Just to make sure I have this right as some of the calculations set out below seem incorrect:

For 1 metric ton of coal containing 3% Sulphur the following applies:

30 Kg of Sulphur requires as calculated in the video: 30000 g of S / 32.065 = 935.59956 moles then as 1 mole of S reacts with 1 moles of CaCo3 = 935.59956 * 100.09 = 93644.159 g which is = 93.64 Kg of CaCo3  to fully neutralize it producing 112.431 Kg of CaSo3. Therefore you need ~ 3.12 Kg of CaCo3 to neutralize 1 Kg of Sulphur.

Knowing this, the approximate answers would be as follows for 1x10^9 metric tons of coal:

The amount of Sulphur produced from 1 metric ton of coal = 30 Kg * 1 billion = 3.0x10^10 Kg of S produced.

The amount of CaCo3 needed for 1 metric ton of coal = 93.64 * 1 billion = 9.364x10^10 Kg of CaCo3 needed (which is 3.121 times the amount of Sulphur produced).

Finally the amount of CaSo3 produced from 30 Kg of Sulphur reacting with 93.64 Kg of CaCo3 = 112.431 * 1 billion = 1.12431x10^11 Kg of CaSo3 produced.

RFM for Sulphur = 32.065 g

RFM for CaCo3 = 100.09 g

RFM for CaSo3 = 120.17 g

Good luck to all!

An Acid decouples from a positively charged Hydrogen ion (the naked proton) via dissociation where the water separates the ion from the acid (i.e HCl becomes H+ + Cl-) and then it finds something that is negatively charged, (a dissociated base NaOH->Na+ + OH-) and get's with the negatively charged group (OH-).Resulting in an overall reaction of HCl + NaOH -> H2O + NaCl. The reaction is mediated by the Hyrdonium and Hydroxide ions the water makes by dissociating the acid and base.

The Khan Academy also has topical videos organized under subjects, but aims at teaching you specific skills.  Production values are typically low, as the focus is your learning and not your enjoyment.

So the Khan Academy is like a classroom, where you may enjoy yourself but the focus is on learning how to do specific things.  Crash Course is more like a documentary, where more staffing hours go into the entertainment part than the education part (even though you still learn something).

That's because Crash Course is primarily entertainment, while the Khan Academy is almost entirely educational.  Crash Course is still *very* educational, but a quick comparative look at how the two programs are structured reveals their differences.

Crash Course has a graphics team, writers, editors, and so on.  The prioritizing of production values marks it as entertainment, even though you will probably learn something without even trying.

Protons are not immovable objects, it's just that often in materials (like metal wires), the protons are involved in the nuclei which are bound to other nuclei and not moving around easily, while the surface electrons are free to move from atom to atom.  So when electricity flows through a wire, it's due to the movement of the surface electrons, not the movement of the protons.

The main component of acid rain are nitric and sulfuric acids produced by interaction of the oxides with hydroxyl radicals.
S + O2 --> SO2
SO2 + HO* (hydroxyl radical) --> HSO3* (bisulfite radical)
HSO3* + O2 + H2O --> H2SO4 + HO2* (hydroperoxyl radical)

The resulting hydroperoxyl radicals react with SO2 (or NO) to produce additional hydroxyl radicals
HO2* + SO2 --> SO3 + HO*

Source: 'Shriver and Atkins Inorganic Chemistry 5ed.',  pg.410  "Acid Rain"

No need to freak out. What we normally call a "proton" when discussing acids and bases is basically just a hydrogen ion. A hydrogen atom contains one proton in the nucleus and one electron "orbiting" it. (The word "orbiting" is a bit misleading, it's close enough for what you're trying to understand here.) Hydrogen contains no neutrons, so when it loses its electron to become an ion, all that's really left is the proton.

So yeah. Just think of it as an ion if that's easier on your brain. :-)

So we know that for one mole of H2SO4 one mole of CaCO3 is needed.
Mass of H2SO4= 98.08 g/mol => (30 kg * 1000 g/kg)/98.08= 305.87 moles of H2SO4.
Since its a 1:1 reaction we also need 305.87 moles of CaCO3.
(305.87 moles * 100.0869 g/mol)/1000 (g/kg) = 30.61 kg per ton
This times a billion equals to: ~3.1*10^10 kg CaCO3 for every billion tons of Coal.

Yes there are 3 main ones, Bronsted-Lowry as in the video, Lewis and Arrhenius. However the Bronsted-Lowry definition is the most accepted. 
Arrhenius said that acids dissociate in water to produce H+ (H3O+) ions and bases dissociate to produce OH- ions. Ammonia (NH3) acts as a base but as it contains no OH- ions Arrhenius' definition does not cover it.
The Lewis definition does expand on the Bronsted-Lowry definition but is much harder to explain so is not used as much.

I get 9.4 million tonnes.
My reasoning was: 3 x 10^13 g of S8 in the billion tonnes of coal. By dividing by 256, this equates to 1.172 x 10^11 mol.
Using the equation S8 + 8O2 -> 8SO2 and the molar ratio of 1:8 I get 9.375 x 10^11 mol of SO2. Then I use the equation
SO2  + CaCO3 -> CaSO3 + CO2 and the molar ratio of 1:1 to get 9.375 x 10^11 mol of CaCO4. I then multiply this by 100 (molar mass of Calcium Carbonate) to get 9.4 x 10^13 g which is equal to 94 million tonnes.

pH is the decimal logarithm of the reciprocal of hydrogen ion activity. Because smaller fractions have larger reciprocals and all aqueous solutions have some free H+ ions, bases have higher pH than acids. As H+ activity increases, the ratio of H+ to the total solution approaches 1, so pH approaches 0. Pure water dissociates slightly, so the fraction of H+ ions in solution is 1/(10^7), or 10^-7. This leads to a pH measure of 7. Water is considered neutral because it produces 1 OH- for each H+.

The different definitions of acids/bases are simply ones that have improved over time; the differences are a history lesson. From memory, the Lewis definitions were fairly simple... An acid, under the Lewis definition, is a proton donor. Basically, a substance that has too many protons, or positively charged Hydrogen ions (since they're just protons without electrons), denoted by a H+ symbol. 
Conversely, a Lewis base is a proton acceptor, or a substance which will receive the proton.
